Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53102-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2019 
 
 
 
 
Supporting the Operational Priority 1 Agenda: 
Strengthening Poverty and Social Analysis 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  GDIH  –  Global Disability Innovation Hub 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  OP1  –  operational priority 1 
  PSA  –  poverty and social analysis 
  SARD  –  South Asia Department 
  SDCC  –  Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
  SDTG  –  Social Development Thematic Group 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) implement Strategy 2030 by strengthening poverty and social analysis (PSA) in 
support of the operational priority 1 (OP1) agenda on addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities.1 The TA will (i) review and update guidance and analytical tools used to identify, 
assess, and address the poverty and social dimensions of ADB’s operations; (ii) provide capacity 
building and technical support for developing member countries (DMCs) on designing and 
implementing projects that focus on strengthening poverty reduction and social inclusion; (iii) 
undertake strategic research on emerging vulnerability and social issues in Asia and the Pacific; 
and (iv) support DMCs in implementing innovative PSA approaches. 
 
2.  The TA was endorsed during the corporate priority framework meeting in November 20182 
and is included in the management-approved 2019 results-based work plan of the Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  After decades of sustained growth, Asia and the Pacific has transformed into one of the 
most dynamic areas in the world, but it also has clear and persistent disparities. Extreme poverty 
has been dramatically reduced, and more than 95% of developing Asia’s population live in middle-
income countries. However, about 264 million people still live below the $1.90/day poverty line, 
and the 1.1 billion  people who live on less than $3.20/day are particularly vulnerable to shocks 
and are at risk of falling back into poverty.4 Income inequality in countries has risen or remained 
at a high level, and significant nonincome disparities exist in access to decent jobs, quality 
education and training, health services, and social protection. Access to and affordability of basic 
services such as electricity, water and sanitation, and transport remain a challenge for many 
people in Asia and the Pacific. Urbanization, climate change, demographic transition, digital 
technology, the changing nature of work, and migration all risk the creation of new vulnerabilities 
and  vulnerable  groups.  Significant  gender  disparities  persist  and  often  intersect  with  other 
vulnerabilities, thereby limiting potential for growth and attainment of equal opportunities for half 
of the population in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
4.  Strategy 2030 acknowledges the complexities of Asia and the Pacific and calls for a focus 
on addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities under OP1. The Operational Plan for 
OP1 highlights the need for all sectors to address the inequality of access to opportunities, 
especially for poor and vulnerable people.5 To do this effectively, robust PSA needs to be 
undertaken to better understand the complex contexts and interaction of social, economic, 
political, and institutional forces in DMCs; anticipate projects’ differentiated impacts on various 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
2  The TA was endorsed during the corporate priority framework meeting in November 2018 with an allocation of $1.25 
million from the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The South Asia Department (SARD) is 
supplementing this with $500,000 (also from TASF-other sources) for social inclusion work in SARD countries.  
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 16 October 2019. 
4  ADB  (Economic  Research  and  Regional  Cooperation  Department).  2018.  Updated  Poverty  Estimates. 
Memorandum. 5 November (internal). 
5  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 1: Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities, 
2019–2024. Manila. OP1 stresses the role of investments in human capital and social protection and the importance 
of quality jobs as necessary enablers for creating inclusive societies that are resilient to risks, have the potential to 
achieve prosperity, and are sustainable.

2 
social groups; and use this information to better address vulnerability in country partnership 
strategies and programs, target projects, and design measures to support inclusion, access, 
affordability, and participation. 
 
5.  Strengthening the capacity of governments to conduct PSA and integrate findings into 
national poverty reduction and social inclusion agendas and project design is needed. In many 
countries, PSA approaches are limited, applied inconsistently, and focused strongly on risk and 
safeguards. They do not (i) address the broader issues of heterogeneity in poverty, vulnerability, 
and inequality; or (ii) incorporate an assessment of the different impacts on poor and vulnerable 
groups,  including  disadvantaged  youth;  older  people;  people  with  disabilities;  and  those 
discriminated against based on their gender, ethnicity, religion, class, or sexual identity. ADB has 
developed  good  guidance  on  PSA,6  which  should  be  updated  to  (i)  address  links  to  the 
Sustainable Development Goals; (ii) outline good practices for all lending modalities (e.g., results-
based lending); (iii) align the analyses for sovereign and nonsovereign projects; (iv) clarify how 
the broad umbrella of PSA should be resourced and organized to feed into project design and 
key areas of analysis, such as gender, participation, and safeguards; (v) integrate guidance for 
selected sectors, such as urban development,7 and develop new guidance in areas such as rural 
development or disability inclusion; and (vi) identify and integrate good practices and tools that 
have been developed in DMCs or by TA and loan projects from ADB or other development 
partners. There is a need to (i) ensure that the tools and guidance better address the diversity of 
issues, social groups, and definitions of poverty and vulnerability across countries and regions; 
(ii) strengthen capacity in DMCs (through ADB projects’ executing and implementing agencies) 
to implement PSA and, with governments and other development partners, develop harmonized 
approaches to monitoring and reporting; and (iii) help ensure that the tools and capacity building 
are adequately aligned with national poverty reduction and inclusivity agendas. 
 
6.  Undertaking strategic research is critical for keeping DMCs and ADB abreast of emerging 
issues and enabling them to address these issues in innovative and comprehensive ways. To 
quickly adapt and develop effective responses to rapid social and economic changes, conducting 
targeted research on emerging poverty and inclusion issues and differential impacts on vulnerable 
populations is necessary. Key areas for investigation include disability inclusion, climate change 
and disaster resilience, migration and displacement, and impacts of technology or other disruptors 
in sectors.8 Disability inclusion is a particular area where targeted research and strengthened 
operational approaches are needed. Of the 1 billion people with some form of disability globally, 
70% live in Asia and the Pacific. Many people with a disability face extreme poverty because of 
lack of access to and exclusion from opportunities. They represent one of the most left behind 
segments of the population. The urban poor are among the most vulnerable to shocks as they 
have fewer assets, are typically excluded from formal decision-making processes, and often live 
in unorganized settlements in the most hazardous parts of cities that are at a higher risk of being 
affected by climate change and disaster-related events. Targeted research in emerging areas will 
help improve the quality of analysis and design of interventions, and facilitate the development of 
a network of researchers and collaborators across DMCs in Asia and the Pacific and improve 
knowledge dissemination. 
 
7.  Supporting innovation in PSA will help create better and more impactful projects and 
replicable approaches. Using technologies such as geographic information systems; designing 
 
6  ADB. 2012. Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis: A Working Document. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2014. Guidance Note: Poverty and Social Dimensions in Urban Projects. Manila. 
8  The work in SARD on gender and social inclusion in the rapidly transforming energy sector is an example of the 
importance of combining targeted research with strong external partnerships and capacity building.

3 
analytical tools to assess gender and other distributional impacts; and developing approaches to 
assess the poverty and social impacts of climate change, economic empowerment, market 
access, and land use will help embed effective approaches and test pioneering ones. 
 
8.  In response to these challenges and issues, the TA will strengthen analytical tools and 
processes for PSA, improve capacity in DMCs, and develop knowledge and collaboration on new 
areas for engagement. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: remaining poverty and inequalities in the 
region addressed (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: pro-poor and social 
inclusion design elements in ADB operations improved.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Analytical tools for poverty and social inclusion updated and shared with 
developing member countries. Effective assessment, from country strategies to project design, 
is necessary to develop a strong focus on OP1 priorities on poverty reduction and social inclusion. 
The TA team will revisit and update the Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis and related 
documentation such as the initial poverty and social analysis and the summary poverty reduction 
and social strategy. The team will also prepare PSA tools, such as guidance notes and tip sheets, 
relevant to the Strategy 2030 operational priorities and sector operations and aligned with DMC 
needs and ADB financial instruments, including for urban sector operations, taking into account 
the need for inclusive design. Taking into account the different financing instruments and nature 
of nonsovereign operations, tools and guidance notes will also be developed to support the 
Private Sector Operations Department’s borrowers and clients. Printing of the handbook, tools, 
and guidance notes will be limited and happen on demand. Training modules will be developed 
and implemented to support capacity building in DMCs. A network of experts across the DMCs 
will be established to support the exchange of good practices and continued capacity building. 
 
11.  To  develop  a  stronger  understanding  of  and  focus  on  poverty  and  the  complex 
intersectionality of social inequalities, the TA team will conduct research and training activities 
with the South Asia Department (SARD) to develop a framework for integrating social inclusion in 
all SARD country operations. Close examination of specific regional issues and applications will 
provide useful lessons and a replicable approach for other regional departments. 
 
12.  Output 2: Strategic research and knowledge exchange on poverty reduction and 
social inclusion strengthened. Disability, climate change and disaster risks, demographic 
transition, digital technology, migration, and displacement are examples of areas where some of 
the greatest change and social impacts are taking place in Asia and the Pacific and new 
vulnerabilities are being created. The TA will support strategic research and collaboration on 
emerging issues to improve knowledge and strengthen operational approaches to addressing the 
differential impacts. Consultative and participatory approaches to identifying opportunities for 
further strengthening social inclusion will be employed in DMCs. Governments, nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), and civil society organizations will be consulted to distill social inclusion 
trends and practices and to identify entry points to strengthen the social inclusion focus and impact 
 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
of ADB operations. Engagement forums on such issues as stocktaking on social inclusion in 
South Asia and male engagement in gender equality will help raise awareness, build common 
understanding, and share international good practices. ADB will engage the services of the Global 
Disability Innovation Hub (GDIH) to support disability inclusion through inclusive design and 
assistive technology. The research studies and engagement forums will inform the development 
of tools and capacity building materials for DMCs (output 1). 
 
13.  Output 3: Innovative approaches to poverty and social analysis applied in selected 
projects. Prioritizing demand at regional and/or country level and using the results of output 2, 
the TA will provide resources for (i) testing pioneering PSA approaches and (ii) integrating the 
analysis of poverty and social issues into the design and implementation of innovative projects 
with strong focus on poverty reduction and social inclusion (including gender). All DMCs and 
regional departments will be eligible to request funds. The criteria, guidelines, and approval 
process are in the attached a supplementary document. . 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.25 million, of which (i) $1.75 million will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and (ii) $500,000 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund10 under the 
Urban Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
15.  Financing by the Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund supports (i) integration 
and leverage, identifying opportunities for scaling up ADB operations in urban development, with 
a particular focus on disability inclusion and climate change resilience; and (ii) knowledge 
generation, dissemination, and use, including developing case studies, practice guides, and other 
knowledge products; and supporting knowledge dissemination platforms that promote sharing of 
lessons between target cities and wider audiences and build evidence around urban climate 
change adaptation in practice.11 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA, with overall coordination by SDCC’s Social Development 
Thematic Group (SDTG) secretariat. The SDTG secretariat will select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants; organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in workshops. 
Given the range of SARD-specific activities, a focal point and support team from SARD will lead 
implementation of those activities and work in collaboration with the SDTG secretariat. A core 
working group will be mobilized from the Gender Equity Thematic Group; NGO and Civil Society 
Center; SDCC’s Safeguards Division; the Private Sector Operations Department; the Strategy, 
Policy,  and  Partnerships  Department;  other  sector  and  thematic  groups;  and  operations 
departments to ensure ownership and provide inputs. Reporting will be made to the SDTG 
Committee to monitor TA progress. 
   
 
10 Financing partners: the Rockefeller Foundation and the governments of Switzerland and the United Kingdom. 
11 Financing by the Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund (UCCRTF) will prioritize countries covered by 
UCCRTF (i.e., Bangladesh, Indonesia, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, and Viet Nam).

5

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.12 The TA will require 39 person-months of international and 90 person-
months of national consultants with expertise in poverty, social development, social inclusion, 
gender and development, climate change and disaster risk, aging, digital technology, disability, 
migration, PSA, social risk and vulnerability assessment, course development and training, and 
project  management  and/or  coordination. Output-based  contracts  will be  considered  where 
appropriate.  
 
19.  The GDIH will be recruited using single source selection to provide consulting services. 
The organization is of exceptional worth for the assignment. Based in the United Kingdom, the 
GDIH is a consortium of 20 entities representing academia, the private sector, and NGOs and 
has a vast network of partners working on disability inclusion and a particular focus on working in 
developing countries. It is a leading institution on inclusive design, smart city development, and 
assistive technology. ADB has been working with the GDIH for more than a year on disability 
inclusion. ADB and the GDIH are working on the implementation of a disability project in Mongolia 
and on a global case study on affordable housing in preparation for an urban development project. 
In Georgia, the GDIH supported the preparation of legislation on inclusive design, which has been 
adopted in Tbilisi and will be used in other urban areas to be supported under the future Livable 
Cities Investment Program (Multitranche Financing Facility).13 Under the TA, the GDIH will build 
on  these  initiatives  to  further  strengthen  disability  inclusion  during  project  design  and 
implementation of urban sector projects. 
 
 
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
13 ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Georgia, 2020-2022. Manila.

6 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund under the Urban 
Financing Partnership Facility and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of 
$1,750,000 on a grant basis for Supporting the Operational Priority 1 Agenda: Strengthening 
Poverty and Social Analysis, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Analytical tools for poverty and social inclusion updated and shared with DMCs  
1.1 Review the Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysisc and incorporate new PSA approaches 
(December 2019–June 2021) 
1.2 Extract guidance notes and tip sheets for sector operations, and package them as a PSA tool kit 
(April 2020–December 2021) 
1.3 Prepare PSA training modules and materials (January 2021–December 2021) 
1.4 Organize PSA training for DMCs to build technical capacity to apply the tool kit in improving project 
design (October 2021–October 2022) 
1.5 Develop SARD framework for social inclusion in operations (January 2020–January 2021) 
2.  Strategic research and knowledge exchange on poverty reduction and social inclusion 
strengthened 
2.1 Identify research areas and undertake research work with development partners such as the 
International Labour Organization, UNESCAP, Rockefeller Foundation, and the Global Disability 
Innovation Hub (January 2020–July 2022) 
2.2 Design and conduct knowledge events by bringing regional and global experts together to share, 
exchange, and develop knowledge solutions (June 2020–December 2021) 
2.3 Design and conduct SARD engagement forums on poverty and social inclusion (June 2020–
December 2021) 
2.4 Engage the services of the Global Disability Innovation Hub to support disability inclusion through 
inclusive design and assistive technology (January 2020–July 2022) 
3.  Innovative approaches to poverty and social analysis applied in selected projects 
3.1 Identify target projects in consultation with operations departments (April 2020–July 2022) 
3.2 Provide technical support to target projects and engage with DMC counterparts (June 2020–July 2022) 
3.3 Document best practices and lessons from supported projects (April 2020–March 2022)

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  GDIH  –  Global Disability Innovation Hub 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  OP1  –  operational priority 1 
  PSA  –  poverty and social analysis 
  SARD  –  South Asia Department 
  SDCC  –  Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
  SDTG  –  Social Development Thematic Group 
  TA  –  technical assistance
